titre_article: Deep Learning Works in Practice. But Does it Work in Theory?

conjectures.text: CONJECTURE 1. *Most of the data from the current state of our universe and most of the problems we aim to solve with these data, as well as any good approximations of these data and problems, have a Kolmogorov complexity larger than 10<sup>9</sup> bits.*

Conjecture 2. Most of the data from the current state of our universe and most of the problems we aim to solve with these data, as well as any good approximations of these data and problems, have a large non-parallelizable logical depth.
Conjecture 3. At equivalent Kolmogorov complexity, deeper neural networks compute functions with larger non-parallelizable logical depth.
